div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Berths can be definitely engaged beforehand. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles, Gibraltar, Plymouth and London are Intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamer leaves Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before.
The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arriving in London at the very convenient hour of 4.56 p.m. on Friday.
The combined Sea and special train fare is £22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Marseilles.
Passengers having paid fall fare in one direction are allowed an abatement of 25 per cent, on returning within 12 months.
In addition to the above regular weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnight of 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London, calling at Malta or Marseilles.
TO THE EAST.

The Mail Steamers leave Suez for Aden and Bombay every Wednesday, and for Australia and China every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Calcutta, fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passengers can embark at Port Said.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.

Formerly the favourite Residence of H.H. the Khedive. Perfect Sanitation.–Purest Desert air. Electric Light. Hot and old baths attached to most rooms. House warmed by special system of Radiators, adjoining the Golf Links and Race Course, Tennis, Billiards, Garden and open air palm house, good stabling , dark room. Excellent Table. Moderate Charges.

div.head: MOHAMED ALY MEMORIAL.
div.p: A few months ego Alexandria, as well as

the rate of Egypt, we celebrating the ontic a Mohamed Aly, theolin of tho Khedivtal dynasty, And the manner whom the country owes so mocha for all he was able to accomplish for its agreement during the early part of the laet Dentary. Few wh- saw the beautiful octet of the illumination of one great square will forget the sight, which, as far aa the day itself 'was concerned, testified to the excellence of the work of the coffinites under whose management it was carried out. But it was naturally felt that some more durable memorial than this was needed to mark the occasion in a proper manner. The committee, therefore, proposed that the pens, of the 'decorations and illumination should be borne by tho Municipality, and that the biorational rained for. th>s purpose behold be devoted insfeid to the object of providing somrj fitting and permanent tribute to the memory of Mohamed Aly.

To the surprise of the community at large tho proposal that this should take the. Shape of a Lunatic Asylnm waa adopted ; only, however *|o be alternately abandoned consequent on the outcry that snow an absurd proposal evoked Here, we believe, the matter rests, and no further iteps have booth taken, nor as

far As we ' can ascertain, are any note- I plated in the immediate future It is hardly - I credible, and certainly not at all . crude-' table to the. City Father*, that, in the first place,- no Bettes memorial of a great man can j be .thought of than a lunatic asylum, and, in ' the' second place, that when snow an idea . U abandoned in deference to public opinion, /ion altar :active plan presents itself for adoption. What could show more plainly how incapable the Egyptian character is of taking the initiative when it devolves noon 'the native] to take independent action T Sorely in stich a matter it ought not to be left to the foreigner to make suggestions. But this is just- what we. in 'end doing.

The city of Alexandria has many wants. Two of these readily ooze to our mind, and while we think that either might be recommended to the notice the committee both, coiid be easily supplied at one and the same time if funds permitted. They are—a Public Library and a Clock Tower. Alexandria once possessed a great and world famed library ; its treasures, which would be of incalculable value to savants were they now available, .perished by fire. What more fitting monument ti Mohamed Aly than the eruption of a building on one of the fine sites available on the now quay, which shall be as worthy of modern Alexandria as the old one was of the ancient city 1 8towed away somewhere in the rear of the Municipal Buildings in Rosetta-street, and approached by a narrow path running along tile side, are, we believe, some 2 >.000 volumes that, properly arranged and catalogued in a suitable building, should be available for reference by the many who at present have no idea of their existence, as well as by the few who, knowing where to go, do use this hidden library when erosion requires. Just now a notice hung on the door informs an that for the present the library is dosed, no intimation being given as to when it is likely to re often. tie would suggest to the .Mohamed Aly Memorial Committee that they at or es open negotiations with the Municipality with a View to joining forgone and go suffering, not only the present generation but many yet to ooze, the means of an education only to be obtained at such an institution air ii public Library. We .make the recommend- - nation with 'the more confidence seeing thit an Art Gallery—an emollient adjuncts te a library—is wanted in order to house the. fine collection of pictures 'which has lately como into the possession of the city. Wo mo. aware, too, that matters of more proving importance will prevent the Municipality from considering suoh'questions as those of tho site df a new Municipal Palace (or as an alternative the enlargement of the presont one), the pro- ^ieion of a new library and art gallery; the extenuation of fbe: Museum,' eto., for a long lime. 'But' why -should Alexandria wait, and perhaps miss an opportunity, that is uot likely Up present itself again, of combining pueblo 'girth private effort for the furtherance of desirable, an object t A look lower would furnish an ornamental as wdl as a u- oful fea'uro to a Publio Library,, and afford somo rirh tiitieeh an. opportunity for presenting the city with a olook with ohimes and carillon . bolls tjimiUr to thoso soon in. so mady continental ' And English towns. Though priority of public (Hooks in this city in too apparent to all to need pointing out, and, in the evont'of falLiro i o seoura tho oo operation of thj Muniofpality fn a scheme for t.ha provision of. a library, perhaps the ereotion of is clock tower and drinking fountain might to the memorial oomtoitteo as a snitable, if less Ambitious; way of porpetuating tho memory of Mohamed Aly. It might, bo simple in con- Strnotiou or it might bj elaborate. A clock tower is just one of. thoso things that lend themselves readily to the elaborate art deoora tion only limited by tho funds available, while is useness admits of no question. Every quarter of an hour the ohimes, every henr ' the bell, and every few. hours the crillon would come Boating on the wind, tejling the citirens the time that is now announce 1 only once in the twenty-four hours by the gun at Fort Kom el Dik.
We are informed that this hotel has never been so frequented as it has been this reason. It has been practically fall since the end of

div.head: Cairp "Zoo."
div.p: The ten Sudanese lion onbs now in the Zoogiral {L-mlens at Ghizah are leaving for India within a few days, so people wishing to see them before their departure are advised' to visit the gardens withbot delay.
French Mission.

M. de Boissien, the French Government expert on the foreign trade that country, hae arrived at Cairo. He hair bean charged by the Frehch Government to make an investigation into the economics of modern Egypt.

div.p: Government gains have been reoordad Bodmin, Harwich. New Forest, Ross, Haywood, Newton Harrow, Tottenham, Henley, and Essex (S. E.) Unionist gam in Lanark shire (N. W.)^ Government undergoes no change in Derbyshire (N.E ), Torquay, Monmouthshire (N.),Norfolk (E.),Rdsholiff, Fromo, Pembrokeshire, Lanarkshire (Mid), Lough borongh. Unionists no change in Ormskirk, Ludlow, Hand«wortb, Kingston, Lewe.r, and Woroestershirle (E.) Mr. Austen Chamberlain increased his majority by 4 366.
London. Thursday, Jan. 25.

The Government has secured 358 seats, the Unionists 137, Nationalists 81. There are still 93 to poll. The Government gains 'td day are thirteen in number, including Watford; Unionists nil. The Labour Party consists of 28 delegates, 11 miners, and 14 independent. They are pledged to seonre an amendment of the faotory, eight-hoar day, and unemployed acts, and State pension fund.

div.head: LORD CROMER.
div.p: Lord Cromer qnd part/ arrived to-day at Wady Haifa from Shollal at 7 a.m., and left by train at 8 a.m., breakfasting in the train.

div.head: EN ROUTE TO PORT SUDAN.
div.p: A large number of officials and Press representatives reached Suez yesterday afternoon by the 4 o'clock train from Cairo, by which they proceeded to the dooks, and embarked on board the Khedivial Mail liner Dikablieh, which sailed at 5.10 p.m. en rente to Port Sudan, to assist at the inauguration of the Nile-Red Sea Railway on Saturday.
The Dakahlieh was specially fitted op for the occasion, and presented a thoroughly smart appearance.

div.head: DEATH OF SOLIMAN PACHA
div.p: We regret to announce the deUh of Sheikh Solimau Pacha, one of tire most distinguished native notables of Alexandria, who expired after an operation owing to an internal complain^ early yesterday morning. The Sheikh'-s family was originally of Algerian origin, and. has been established in Egypt for over a century. The deceased was among the largest landlords in Alexandria and also owned the Mosqne Gama el Shqikh and the Moslem university near that mosq'uD. The Sheikh was very learned in Moslem law. He was a broadminded man and wae very friendly to Europeans. He took a great interest in religions, philanthropic, and educational works. He was 65 years of age. Tne funeral took plaoe yesterday afternoon.

div.p: Port Said. Wednesday.

div.head: TO BE INAUGURATED TO-MORROW.
div.p: The unsatisfactory port of Suakin will be definitely superseded to-morrow by a brand new rival on the Red Sea, which has been built up oat of ooral rook and desert sand by the Egyptian authorities within the short spsce of less than a year, and -/hioh will be officially inaugurated by Lord Cromer tc-mor row. Port Sudan, the latest addition to the oities of the Empire (and destined to be a place of magnitude and importance, in tho days when cotton shall have- made it the New Orleans of the East) was, natil last 'January and is now on all the maps, called Mersa Sheikh Bargont. To mariners /t was a little khor, or harboor, given on their charts of that seaboard, but never need. At the northern part of the entrance stand the ruins of a tomb, looking from passing vessels like a cottage— and visible at a distance of twenty miles on a dear day—the borial place of Sheikh Bargont.

Saakin has long been considered a por.t of dangerous apprcaoh by navigators. A loBg, forty-mile channel leads to it, fall of awkward coral. At the present time there are several fine steamers come to grief near it, and standings have been of too frequent occurrence. Indeed, so frequent, that there are plaoes in the channel where, when a steamer gronnda, the danger is minimised by the fact that other vessels have been there before her, and have made the berth an easy one. Bnt for some time, past the Government has been pnshiDg forward the ooDfttrnotion of the Sadan-Berbera'Railway, which rons down to 8aakint and the consequently heavy shipments to the latter port, and ensuing groundings, opened the eyes of the authorities to the fact that when the Sudau was aotually a territory of commMoial importance Suakin would be no plaoe to deal with the produce on the seaboard. It% accommodation was too bad.
Description of Port.

In Jinnary la^t year his Majesty's ship Sealark was sent to. survey the whole ooast, and to report on possible sites with a view to a port which oould replace and better Saakin. In the same month Sir William Garstin visited 8heikh Bargont, and his advice ied to that site being decided npon to make a new plaoe on the map. Portftadan is about s:x hundred and eighty miles snath of Saez, and is capable of holding a dozen vessels of moderate size. The entranoe is six hundred feet across, and divides into two ohannels of good depth. The land ronnd it is aboat sis feet above sea level— quite a considerable elevation for that flat seaboard—and forming an admirable base * for wharves. Moreover, it* is sure to be in the very near futire (cotton or none) a ooaling station of considerable importation and one now greatly needed, for at present there is .none b tween Perim and Suez, a distance of thirteen handred mile'.. Brit beyond all its advantages it has a good supply of fresh w&tsr, Th1 supply at Suakin Unit only small bit bad.

Already the plaoe bears the appearance from seaward of being a station of considerable substance. It is true tfiat in England none but a few officials would know how to find Port Sadan on the chart, but the intentions of the Government no sooner leaked^nV than an army of pioneers personally found the spot very quickly, and the mushroom station was over, ran With Italians, Greeks, Arabs, etc. They went with all they owned, mainly a tent, an iron pot, and a frying-pan, and the desert strand whispered prosperity a few months after 8ir William Garstin's favourable report. Others, with more forethought, knowing the timborless oonntry to which they were going, took a little wood with them, whioh, with mats and bamboos- soon gave a few straggling streets to Port Sadani
Signs of Activity,

The Sadan Government haa bnilt substantial w rehouses, a quarantine station, a hospital, and a number of offitts, so that approaohing the new harbonr from seaward it already bears the appearance of a place of activity and trade. As evidenoe that the Government expect great things of the Sadnn, when the railway is completed, and the plant i- fciona have proceeded beyond the experimental stage, it should be noted that last May tenders were invited for a powerfal light to be oor- straoted at Port Sadan, whioh should show an ooonlting beam for a distanoe or twenty-dour miles. It is being e/eoted oq Sanganeb Reef, which is e&at of the' port by thirteen miles, and near it will be located & pilot station. Farther, the. Sadan

div.head: ALEXANDRIA SPORTING CLUB
div.p: The annual general meeting of the olnb will be held at the Khedivial Club on the 9th February next at 6 p.m., when the balanoe sheet and the aooounta of the past year will be laid before the meeting and the offioers and the committee for the ensuing year elected. The olob has had a very profitable year. The total increase of the net profits over the figures for last yea* was about £400, notwithstanding the extraordinary expenditure of nearly £irO for repairing the grand stand, etc. The following expenditure was made daring the past year, the amounts being in piastres tariff:—fctat aocount, 45,000 ; games, 35,551 ; course, 39,403 ; gymkhana, 1,576 ,* wages, 6,120; charges, 16,676 ; extra expenditure, 16.85S; office expenditnre, 32,725, amount irrecoverable on old debts 1,229. The subscriptions smonnted to P.T. 119,133, as against P.T. 110,862 in the preceding year. The races and lotteries aoooont was P.T. 139,738, as against P.T. 110,761 in 1904. The donations last year were as followi : - Khedivial dab, P.T. 3,900 ; Government, P.T. 20,000 ; Alexandria & Ramleh Railway, P.T. 2,090; Manioipality, P.T. 5,000 ; Prinoe Mohamed Ibrahim, P/l\ 5,000 ; Alexandria Athletic Sports, P.T. 915. The rent of paddock stalls and the regifttra tion lees on jockeys and colours amount to P.T. 12,495, £11 less than last year.

div.head:
THE YELLOW PERIL.
CHINESE MINISTER INTERVIEWED
CHINA TO BECOME MODERN NATION

div.p: Wan-ga tah-sieb, the new' Chinese Minister, interviewed by a representative of Renter'* Agency, said that China would undoubtedly follow Japan's example and do her best to beoonie a modern nation, with a new army in the Booth formed on Western methods, and similar to those in Hupeh and the North.

He ridiculed the idea of the Yellow Peril, saying an aili&noe between China and Japan at present seemed impracticable, bat peaceful development made China's relations with England, America, and Japan oloser and closer, so that a formal alliance would be unnecessary.

div.head:
The emperor of China
APPOINTMENT OF SUCCESSOR.

div.p: The Dowager Empress has ordered all eligible Princes to b$ presented on the oc casion of the New 'Year. She Will then ohooso three or four, and one of these will eventually be taken as the successor of the Emperor. (Reuter)

div.head:
Germany and Abyssinna
THE NEW TREATY.

div.p: The .treaty between'Germany and Abyssinia bee been presented to the Reichstag. It secures larger privileges as regards liberty of sojourn, travel, trade, and industry than Great Britain or America possess. .(Reuter)

div.head:
Reduction of Expenditure
NO HOPE THIS YEAR.

div.p: Speaking at Kingsbarnei, Mr.';Asquith declared that,. anzions as the Government was to rednoe expenditure, he saw little hope of doing so during the current year. (Reuter)

div.head:
Government and Ireland
NO COMPACT WITH LEADERS.

div.p: fyeakiog at Berwiok, Mr. Haldane emphatically deolared that no compact nor an- dent&nding exists between the Government and tha Irish leaders for the establishment of a Statutory Parliament for Ireland, or for the introduction of a bill for snoh a parpose.
(Reuter)

div.head: TWO BOOKS OF VERSE
div.p: The Infant Moralist. By Mrs. Arthur Jacob anti Lady Helena Carnegie. Edinburgh: 'R.Cimnt and Son, 10?. Princes-street; Lolidon: R. Brimlev Johnson.- Verses. By. Violet Jacob (Mrs. Arthur Jacob). London r.Willianr Heifiemann.

These books will commend themselves more especially to those who knew the authoress while sh9 was in Egypt in 1903 and 1904 ; bat they are well worth consideration on' every other coant. Let ns take first 1 he "Infant Moralist," a series of poems with pictures that would have appealed in all seriousness to dor greatgrandfathers. Imagine Jane and Ann Taylor, pins Dr. Watts, pins the Fairchild Family the whole tinged with the sobtleet possible 19th-centnry honour, jost that_ pumour, so nearly -imperceptible,which can torn an ohvioos "moral tale" into a treasure and a joy for ever. It is better to quote a few lines, and let readers jpdge for then selves. We have, in one poem, on "Profanity," 'certain lines apropbs of Para: ^keets (observe the antique flavour of "Parakeets" instead of parroqaeta or other snoh Dames)
"How Btrnngo a sight in distant, lauds Where wonders meet the eye,
To see the works of nature's hands , From every tree-top fly.I"
We have again, from "Heartless Folly," the awful story of the shameless youth who tripped up the benevolent Admiral, and made a mook
of him..
What should you feel if Admiral Bligh Were taken from us to tho sky,
And you should bo'tho cause ? .
Oh, wretched boy, Elisha's bears May even now be on the stairs Your punishment to give:
For those the Aged^who'oflend, .
Are like to come to fearful end Or else in chains to live."
We could qaote many more lines : indeed we oannot refrain from two :—
"Where heathons'roam in impious bands,
And feast upon their. f.oes."

The delightfal accuracy, of the 1820 1630 touch in. every other word, gives to these poems a certain savour, as of caviar, to modern readers. 'We will say no more^ except to counsel all who possess a sense of humour—happily , almost auiversal in these days—to procure the book ; for it is a book to have and to keep, and only to lend—against receipt—to those ohosen spirits who appreciate—and return— such works.

"Verses," by Violet Jacob, are the serious side of an authoress whose very sense of humour should make her serious work the more notable. The two points of view must always be combined, to attain to insight and understanding. We might quote Mr. Caine and Miss Corelli in support of our contention: eaffice it to say that these veree3 are the work of one who can see and appreciate both sides . of life. Technically speaking, as verse, they are of a high order : the subjects and the . thought are by no means common place, but the chief interest in them' is a certain regret, a keen and pitiful observation of fife, oonjoint with an acute and compensating Jove of nature —nature which always remains, impassive, hated perhaps in some moment ef pain, but gradually, by her eternal presence, healing sufferer* to forgetfulness. Even one er two stray phrases in a book, suggesting this, are of valne, and in these verses there ar9 many snob. These are lines that stand out :
"I have a little poison flower *
I gathered there : arid, though I would forget,
/ take it out in some friend-haunted hour Tufind it living,yet."
V And agaiD, of a faneral in the East, one of those funerals we all know here, sndden, unexpected, moving us in cur daily work, and— soon forgotten: —
"Forward the dead march rolls : >
K6ep we our souls
Strong for the last that love can do for hfm."
Bat that whole poem is worth reading, and remembering yet another poem has at least a touch of the greater magic, "The Call," especially in the second part : —
I wifi arise and'-steal upon the stair,
Whore the tall clock counts up Timo's gathered
[hoard
Telling its numbers to the empty air."

All this may seem to be undoly high praise for a slight book of verse ; yet sorely all praise is dae to words and lines that oan touch us intimately. We may treasure the intensity of Browning, or shiver at the sensuous sweep of Swinburne : we may marvel a moment at the far-off ring and clash of the ' Recessional " (that last, however, we coqld put aside not withoat a feeling of ease that it has been said for ns, sparing us fortber thought upon the subject); but there are times, when -some quieter line comes hack,haunting and consoliDg, very near to something we know. Snoh a line 18 a possession, and in its hour, when the greater poets are pet aside, we valne it even above thofe of high and approved geninses, whose thoughts are not ours,and cannot speak to us in that hour.

div.head: CAPE TO CAIRO RAILWAY
div.p: PREDICTION THAT IT WILL NEVER BE BUILT

Nilns writes as follows to the editor of the "New York TimesIn the "Times" of this date the bridge acre sb the Zambezi is described as on the Cape to Cairo Railroad? As the northern portion of this railway does not yet extend from Cairo to Khartoum by a tinnons line of rails, and as it is a simple impossibility, in view of the total absence of population, the exceptionally malarious climate, and* the venomous character of the mof quiloes" to bnild a railway from Uganda to Khaitonm on the high land to the west of the "sndds," or obstructions in the vast swamps, where the water from the lake regioo ceases to maintain an open channel1, it is obvioas that the term is a misnomer.

It was used for Parliamentary and popular purposes, but the London "Times" ounce led several months ago that no such continuous all-rail route would ever be constructed. Ismail Paoha spent over $ 1,500 000 in surveys and explorations, chiefly under the direction of American officers. They were "Englished" as the work of Sir John Fowlor, and credit given him on- the map of the British War Office, printed in 1882. But it was the General Staff, from 1870 to 1878, under Lieut. Gen. Stone Pacha, which did the work.

It would be interesting if the "Times" would publish, a brief sketch of the Assouan Reservoir, based on the artiole in'the engineering supplement of the London "Time?," Aug. 16. describing the "separation walls (buttresses) and "downstream apron," which are being added to this struotnre to support the tottering wall, and prevent further seams in the bed. ot the Nile. Info-mation on this point oan be obtained from a Consular report issaed by the State Department.

In another Consular report, it is said that the oottep crop beforo the diim was completed was large; than it has -ever been since the pompous inauguration of\the structure by the Duke of Connaught. Yes the cotton boom under Mr. Solly must have stimulated every fellah to grow as much as he could.

On the back of the Assouan trolley ticket tho net gain from the Assouan Reservoir is said to have been $ 20,000, but this annual revenne appears to have gone, according to Lord Cromer, into the pockets of' the grafters, who bought up the land-in 1895-8, and unloaded in 1903.
EGYPT AS THE WORLD'S GRANARY.

Before the Royal Geographical Sooiety last week Major A. St. Hill Gibbons read an interesting paper on " British East African plateau land and its eoonomio conditions," in the course of which he stated that two essential conditions to progress were the existence Of markets and lines of communications; but by the time a colony reached even the early stage of development, of which East Africa was at present an example, a local market already existed capable of purchasing on good terms all that eariy industry could produce. Step by step, as settlers poured in and industry expanded, little markets and lines of communication were developed. The Nile was the natural outlet of Uganda and North-western" British East Africa, and, with engineering enterprise and expense quite trivial as oompared with wbat had already been done in Egypt, could be made navigable from Lake Albert to Upper Egypt. Indirectly and directly Sir W. Garatin's great ecbeme Tor the canalisation of the Nile from Bor to Fasboda should do much for these protectorates. The gTeat work would, so .vastly widen the area of cultivation as to Te-establish Egypt as one cf the world's greatest granaries. With the establishment of this now era and with a navigable waterway through the cataract district to the Mediterranean, the Mediteranean sea freights would become proportionate to those on the Atlantic, and Uganda would share the advantage with Upper Egypt—for a few days longer in a Nile barge would not materially add to expense in transit.

div.head: EGYPTIAN SHARE MARKET
div.p: To all intents and purposes the elections are over, and it is wonderful how calmly the City takes the situation. It is realised that the larger the majority the Liberals get ro much the larger is the number of votes polled for them by former Conservatives. No one believes that the latter have so changed their views as to instantly become men of another class, and as the stability of the Government will depend upon the support of this lairge. section of the community, it is obvious that the Liberals cannot afford to take any vital step calculated to reduce the strength or impair the integrity of the Empire. In other words, the larger the majority the greater the security for moderate measures. Even the rankest Conservative would not have been oontent for the entire old team to be re-harnessed again. It is evident that a fatal mistake was made by Mr. Balfour in not dissolving Parliament upon some definite issue of redistribution,for example, and thus enabling the election to be fought out on a particular question rather thau on the candidates themselves. No one olaims that the fiscal or any other question has been settled by this election, as the evident desire to give the other side a turn has been the main cause ot the great change that has taken place. From the City's point of view there are many things that oould be better managed than they were managed during the last regime. The late Chancellor of the Exchequer was considered a weak man in his Treasury dealings with the City,, which has freely complained of being "messed aboot" inthis respect.

There, is hope, therefore, for a stronger and a better hand both to deal with Treasury business and also to effeot economies and reductions in taxation, which it is felt can well be oarried ont without impairing the efficiency of any part of his Majesty's services.

While the City has proclaimed itself a supporter of Mr. Chamberlain in the matter of fisoal reform; no one is sorry to see the question postponed, as the trade of the country shows a new prosperity, which it would perhaps be well to leave alone for the time being. Tho Money Position.

Money is still tight, notwithstanding the very favourable Bank return, which shows a proportion of reserve to liabilities of 42.89% against 33.50% lastweek.The most Conservative disponntand banking institutions have thought it Well to prepare for the worst arising out of the Moroooo Conference. Although the "probability ot any trouble oooarring has now passed away, as long as the possibility exists the same ultra cautions attitudo will be assumed. As soon, however, aa the conference is satisfactorily ended there is every prospect of greater ease in the money market, in addition to whioh large sums have still to borne baok from the provinces, and these will strengthen the reserve of the Bank of England still further. Con a oi/o.

The future of Consols is now thought to be bettor than at any time ainoe the beginning of tho war. The Atorm olonds are now rapidly disappearing from the political horizon. Yesterday the price of Consols rose to 90 , and they close to night At 90.
Railways.
H me railway retarns continue satisfactory, and the dividends as a whole are better than were ant:c pated. With the improving trade these securities are probably at a low price to-day.

A strong tone has prevailed in the American market, and this morning all the shares opened well above parity. On the publication of a farther inorease of 275,000 dollars in the traffic receipts of the Canadian Pacific the shares were bid up to 181. They leave off to-day at 181 }.
Foro/gn Bonds,

Among Foreign Government bonds Russians have again been in favour, but the price shows little change on last week. The Fours are now quoted at 85.' Japanese securities are steady. The new loan stands at f premium.
Egyptians.

The Egyptian market has been quite lifeless and devoid of interest sinoe our last, and prices have hardly moved. National Bank of Egypt have been steady at 25$, but to-day advanced to 25 Agricultural Banks are unchanged at 9 and the last issue at 9. Daira Sanieh have been dealt in to a small extent on the basis of 17 , and the Deferred at 104. Union Fonoi&re and Abyssinian Batiks are quite unmentioned at £—l &nd i—£ premium respectively. Delta Preference Bearer have farther fallen to 11} on the unsatisfactory dividend, and there seem to be no buyer* about. Delta Land and Investment are nominally 2. Rank of Ronmania have again been in demand, apd clone 7 J — 8|. Egyptian Markets are 1| .and Silt and Soda 1 There is nothing to say regarding the lower-priced shares, and Khedivial Mail have not once been quoted.
Mining.

In the South African market Premier Dia-, moods havo developed strength under the influence of a message reoeived from the di- rootore expressing implicit oonfidenoe in the mine, and stating that the present yield dees not represent, the mine's trnevalue.lt is reported that in the Cindeiella Deep the main reef has been entered at a depth of 4,000 feet, and that the reef is 9ft 6" wide. div.head: THE COTTON MARKET
div.p: There has been an improved demand for Egyptians this wcok, and quotations of Good Fair to Fine Brown, and Good Fair and Fully Good Fair Upper are raifted 1/16 per lb. In Futures a good business has been done, and tho following are the latest values :—
Jany. 8.6 Apl. 8.6 July 8.5
Feby. 8.6 May 8.6 Aug. 8.5
Mob. 8.6 June 8.6 Nov. 7.47

American Futures.—The market this week has been active and there have been sharp fluctuations ; a decline of 6 @ 8 points was followed by an advance of 21 points from the lowest; this in turn has been partially lost, to-day's closing values being 11 @ 13^ points below the extreme rates touched, but 2 @ 4 pointsAbove last Thursday's prices. There is no special feature. At the decline consumers bought largely, trade conditions iemaining satisfactory, and at the advance the Amerioan markets again offered more freely, and, as there is not much fresh speculation, free offerings qoiokly stffeot values. So far the Crop movements indioate a yield of 10£ to 11 millions, whioh would apparently be an ample supply, but, on the other hand planters can control the supply whenever prioes become too depressed for their liking.

div.head: AFFAIRES DE PREEMPTION
div.p: l'affaire de preemption Hadji Bazilion oon- treBacbrDaner a dtd plaidds mardi par devanl ia 2me Chambre civile da Tribunal mixte du Caire.
Le miniature' public, par l'organe de Beyram bey, a dtabli le point 'de droit de preemption par ses conclusions, desqqelles nous avons pn retenir lea- passages principaux :

" Notre mission, dit M. le sabstitat B yram -bey, do oonsiste pas k appliquer litteralement la loi, mais elle oonsiste sartont k approprier son application aux circonstances, k l'fcarmori- sdr avec les evenements, tonten la maintenant intaote dans son esprit,

"Par suite de la pro'ipdritd progressante do payB, par suite de mille oiroonstanoes va- riee8, dont.la speculation tient une large part, nous avons vu C38 derniers mois, les prix des terrains changer de oouw, non seulement dn jour an lendemain, mais dans la mdme journee, do matin an soir.

11 Dans ces conditions le preempteur, qui selon l'esprit de la loi, ne devrait prendre que le lieu et place de 1'aeheteur, et non plus, par ce fait senl'qa'il preempte -qainze jours aprds l'achat realise un benefice appreciable et il se place 8ur une position beaucoup plus avanta- gease que oelle de I'acheteur qui pour arriver a oonclure l'aohat aura deponed son temps, son activite et parfois aura compromis ses interns en maDqnant de faire une autre affaire.

" fiat-il juste, est il equitable dks lors, d'ac- cueillir k bras ouverts le prdempteur ? On me dira peat6tre : dura lex sed lex; je repondrai, oui, la loi accorde la preemption utile et dcono- mique, mais elle n'a jamais entendu rendte la preemption un instrument dangereux, en faire un levier puissant k la speculation. II faut ad- mettre le preempteur mais avec beaucoup de reserves."
Beyram bey cite alors les avis des jaris- consaltes masulmans pour etablir que selon le droit masulman, source de la prdemptioD, ce droit est consider comme un droit faible.

" La jurisprudence mixte, dit M. le substitute a essayd autant qa'elle a pu de restrain- dre ce droit. C'est ainsi qa'elle a decide que le droit de preemption n'existe pas pour les tar- rains lotisds et ofiertaktouB ceuxqui voulaient les acbeter.
C'est ainsi qu'elie ajugeque d'aprks une coutume locale k laquelle les Codes mixtes n'ont pas ddrogd, le droit de preemption s'eteint par la mort du preempteur.

"Or, ajoute Beyram bey, si la jurisprudence d'il y a qde!que8, anndes, a admis oes justes restrictions, les conditions actaelles de la haasse noas font an devoir imperieox de la restreindre encore toutes les fois que nous en avons I'occasion. Le procks aotuel, .dit M. le sabstitat, noas fournit oette occasion. II s'agit de savoir, et c'est le point de droit qui a pose dans oette ffaire, ei le prdempteur peat, ldgaleraent, readier l'acte d'achat de i'acbetear, uniqaement parce que cet acte ne ports pas date oertaine: en d'aatres termes. le prdempteur eat-il un tiers au sens de Tart. 293 du Code oivil.

La loi n'a voulu ddfendre par cat article, dit M. le substitute que les ayant cause des parties oontraotantes, elle D'a pas voula ddfendre tons les tiers, suitoat oeax qai n'ont qu'un droit faible, tel que le droit de preemption. Or un droit, qui ne passe pas aox hdri tiers est un droit fragile, que la loi n'a pu mettre sur le mdme plan qa'un droit entier, forme, un droit proprement dit

A l'appui de catte tbkse, M. Beyram bey cite l'opinion de M. le professeur Planial, de la Faoultd de droit de Paris, et il oonolat au ddboutement de Hadji Baziiiou parce que celoi-ci n'a achetd son terrain qa'un mois aprks que M. Bucbr Duner a achetd le sien par un acte sous seiog privd ne portant pas date certaine.

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera, and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list showing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:-
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 4 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers, of the P.&O. North German Lloyd, Orient and Messageriea Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, and Bibby Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said, can now be made without change in 4 1/2 hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.
The most expensive but quickest through Continental routes are by P.&O. Brindisi express from Port Said, and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis” to Brindisi. One of these leaves port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; hero there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Donino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: LAKE OF LUCERNE. Grand Hotel, Axen-Fels.
div.p: Best Spring resort. 2,200 ft. above the sea. Every comfort.

The leading Hotel for English and American families. Trains every fifteen minutes by Electric Railway from Brunnen to Axen-Fels. The Park having a frontage of nearly a mile on the lake, is one of the prettiest in Switzerland.
World-wide reputation.
P: Sohnack, Proprietor
Level Wooded Walks.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange ; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea, no hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza :

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino.and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO, may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of lake Maggiore has a mild climate and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, "Entombment," by Ciseri, and 'Tho Flight into Egypt,” by Bramantion.
LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne, to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse

A delightful exeption from Lucerne is that to ENGELBERG. Take boat to Stansstad and from Stansstad it is about 1 hour and 40 min. by Electric Railway, with delightful scenery en route. The ascent of Titlis, is made from here, and the panoramic view of the Alps is grand; extending from Monte Rosa to the Black Forest, and from the Santis to the Matterhorn.

THE BERNESE OBERHAND.-INTERLAKEN a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbath and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D'OEX. 3,500 ft above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.

div.p: From Vernon or Lido, 12 min by steamboat. Climatic Station and Sea Baths, with Chinesitherapic Institute. Express between the station and Lido for the hotels.

div.p: The most important bathing station in Italy. ____ Restaurant and Terrace on the sea. Hydrotherapic institute. Concerts daily, frequented by the highest classes of society.

div.head: GRAND HOTEL DES BAINS.
div.p: Adjoining the sea. First-class hotel with dependencies & chalets. 200 rooms & saloons. Electric light. Aqueduct. Every modern comfort. Delightful residence, without any mosquitos.

div.head: THE GRAND HOTEL LIDO.
div.p: Hotel with its dependencies (Swiss Hotel), in the most delightful situation of the Lido at the landing place, five minutes walk from the bathing place. Wonderful view of the Legune of Venice. Room from 3 lire, with board from 8.50 per day. No mosquitos. Very dry and safe air.
Address- SOCIETE BACHI, LIDO, VENICE, ITALY.
